posts.title: Understanding Frontend Development in Depth
posts.body: Frontend development involves creating the visual and interactive elements of a web application. It includes HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and libraries or frameworks like React, Vue, or Angular. Developers focus on usability, performance, and responsiveness to deliver a great user experience.

posts.title: Getting Started with JSON Server
posts.body: JSON Server is a quick and easy way to mock a REST API using a simple JSON file. It supports all HTTP methods and comes with features like filtering, pagination, and full CRUD operations. It’s ideal for prototyping, frontend development, and testing.

posts.title: React Query: Fetching and Caching Data Made Easy
posts.body: React Query simplifies data fetching, caching, synchronization, and background updates in React apps. It allows developers to focus on UI while handling retries, pagination, and invalidation logic under the hood.

posts.title: Best Practices for Writing Scalable React Components
posts.body: To build scalable React apps, structure your components for reusability, use proper folder organization, prefer composition over inheritance, and manage state wisely using hooks or external libraries like Zustand or Redux.

posts.title: Developing a Modern Web App with Next.js 15
posts.body: Next.js 15 introduces a more powerful App Router, allowing developers to build server-first React apps with enhanced performance and better API management using file-based routing.

posts.title: Integrating React Query with JSON Server
posts.body: React Query combined with JSON Server enables fast UI updates, optimistic mutation, and robust caching. It’s a great combo for frontend developers needing real API-like behavior in development.

posts.title: Advanced Pagination with TailwindCSS and React
posts.body: Implementing pagination in React using TailwindCSS provides great flexibility and styling. You can combine custom pagination logic with UI components to manage large datasets with ease.

posts.title: Modal Management using Context API in React
posts.body: Managing modals globally in React using Context API helps in keeping only one modal mounted at a time and simplifies the state management for complex UI interactions.
